div1.p: Hench requests that Simpson show his yellow fever material to a publisher for possible publication.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Walter M. Simpson, June 7, 1941
div1.p:
I felt very flattered to have you and June come to the luncheon
as my guests. It gave me a sense of confidence to have at least some of my
own friends present.

I haven't forgotten my promise to get you a photograph of Kissinger
autographed.

You were kind enough to say that you were going to propose to
Hoeber that he might publish my talk. I didn't have time to tell you that
I have been in a quandry as to what to do with this material. I sent a
manuscript something like this to Siegerist and told him I didn't know
whether it should be published as an article or whether I should save all
my material and publish it as a monograph. He strongly suggested that I
use it as a monograph, and I don't know whether he was trying to let me
down easily and not take the manuscript or not. Young Hoeber was here a
month or so ago and I discussed briefly with him this monograph, but he
didn't show the slightest interest in it even though I told him of the new
discoveries we had made regarding Lazear and others, and of our rediscovery
of Camp Lazear. Nevertheless, I let you have the manuscript as I was
interested to see what reaction you might receive, and I should appreciate
it if you would let me know in confidence his reaction to it. They might
shy away from the commercial angle but you will remember that the manuscript
that I gave you does not once mention the Wyeth people. It merely once or
twice mentions Mr. Law and his colleagues and the title of the paper would
be of course only as given, mentioning only Mr. Cornwall. Whatever happens
I certainly appreciate your interest in the manuscript.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
